All languages have ways to express causation but differ in the means. Most, if not all, languages have lexical causative forms.
English:
rise → raise, lie → lay, sit → set (make something sit)
saint ⇨ sanctify (faire=do)
glad ⇨ gladden (dan,done,do)

Related to perfective completive

In Egyptian the causative is marked by prefix 𓋴 's' or 𓅨(faire) or suffix 𓇋𓀁(faire)

𓋴- causa- cause- cess- syn- sym- set- zu- zum- con- 𓋴𓈖- 𓋴𓅱- sich- self- se- ge- Γ
𓋴- Γ- s- 𓐍- 𓊃- causative vs s⇨h⇨ø erosion !

𓋴- ϭⲓ sei be…

𓋴- sur ⲉⲣ- ⲉ- ⲉ!

𓁹 ⲓⲉⲣ ⋍ ⲓⲣⲓ faire ⲁⲣⲓ > ver… re-… ⲉⲣ- er-… ⲟⲩ- ⲓⲣⲓ ⲛⲃⲉⲣⲓ = renew, erneuern, make new
ⲟⲩⲣⲟ: king ⇨ ⲉⲣⲟⲩⲣⲟ be king, reign ⇔ ⲓⲣⲓ ⲛⲟⲩⲣⲟ make king

See gunu ?

In Coptic interestingly a harder form ϯ ƒt fait… is used
ⲕⲉⲛⲓ fat => ϯⲕⲉⲛⲓ make fat 𓈎 𓈖 𓄃

ϯ- ⲧ- to… forms
ⲧⲥⲁⲓⲱⲟⲩ make beautiful

ⲕⲃⲱⲟⲩ n. cool(ness)
ⲧⲕⲃⲟ make cool
ϯⲭⲃⲟⲃ make cool

Ubiquitous prefixes in IE languages.
Contrast the repetitive component of re- versus the causative component of german er ir- *uʀ- ver… ⇔ over faire

𓋴 𓂦 𓂋 𓏜 consecrate, sanctify

In Cuneiform it may be expressed via
𒋗 šu® or the «generator» GUNU ⋍ 𒆦 ligature
𒅆 IGI Auge eye
𒅊 IGI{GUNU} be bright, shine, see
𒄩 kud : cod-fish ⇨
𒋗𒄩 šu'kud Catcher: Fisher (causative/always reverse)
𒀾𒆲𒋙 áš-kun-šú establish
𒀾𒆲 as2-kun accomplish
𒀊𒆪𒉡 is-ku-nu accomplish
𒊍𒁁 az-bat 𓃀 expede

𒋗𒆰𒌅 šu-qul-tu se.kaal™ scaledom scaled “weight”
𒋗𒆰𒌅 šu-qul-tu se•kauriþa 𐌺𐌰𐌿𐍂𐌹𐌸𐌰 kuruz 𐌺𐌰𐌿𐍂𐌿𐍃 𐌺𐌰𐌿𐍂𐌴𐌹 kaurei™ “weight”

𒂊 ᵍe ʱe ᵏe ᵞe' a' > 𓋴 causative

In Akkadian the Š-stem is formed by adding a prefix š-, and these forms are mostly causatives.
Causative or intensive forms are also formed with the doubled D-stem. გა DO (Tat)

𓐍𓂋𓀒𓂝 crumble,fall down ⇨ 𓊃 𓐍 𓂋 𓀒 𓂝 screw/throw down

salt is the optional causative of halt(bar) halltu, alt-bar (old-preserving, durable)

𓎛 𓌴 𓏏 𓈒 𓏥 salt|halltu@cym Halaitz ἁλίζ αλάτι aláti ἅλς háls
𓎛 𓌴 𓏏 𓈒 𓏥 salt|𓋴• shalis saletz ال.صلت=salt Salz 塩 しお shio(l) 石 só suola соль сіль नुन sol

Coptic prefixes

à- ⲉ- to
er- ⲉ- to

ⲉⲣ- ver-
ⲉⲣ- zer-
ϫⲓⲛ- ⋍ -ing see syn

main => remain
